This word often considered a Wanderwort, with similarity to Akkadian ğ’„ (pilakku, pilaqqu, â€œwooden handle; spindle, harpâ€), itself from Sumerian ğ’„ (balag, â€œwooden handle; spindle, harp; possibly a split piece of wood or wooden wedgeâ€); compare Arabic ÙÙÙ„ÙÙ‚Ùâ€ (falaqa, â€œto split apartâ€) and Ï€Î­Î»ÎµÎºÎºÎ¿Î½ (pÃ©lekkon, â€œaxe handleâ€). This has led some to suggest that the Proto-Indo-European terms are ultimately borrowed through the Akkadian or a Semitic source.
